{{Short description|Complex set of issues and debates surrounding education for girls and women}} {{Educational research}}[[File:Guinea schoolgirls.jpg|thumb|280 px|Schoolgirls in [[Guinea]]]] {{Feminism sidebar}} '''Female education''' is a catch-all term for a complex set of issues and debates surrounding education ([[primary education]], [[secondary education]], [[tertiary education]], and [[health education]] in particular) for girls and women.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Усамов |first=И.Р. |title=Digital Transformation of Education: Challenges and Prospects |date=2019-12-18 |journal=Вестник ГГНТУ. Гуманитарные и социально-экономические науки |volume=3 |issue=17 |doi=10.34708/gstou.2019.17.3.021 |s2cid=242230851 |issn=2686-9721|doi-access=free }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last1=Osler |first1=Audrey |last2=Vincent |first2=Kerry |date=2003-12-16 |title=Girls and Exclusion |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.4324/9780203465202 |doi=10.4324/9780203465202|isbn=9781134412839 }}</ref> It is frequently called '''girls' education''' or '''women's education.''' It includes areas of [[gender equality]] and access to education. The education of women and girls is important for the [[Poverty reduction|alleviation of poverty]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Osman |first=Abdal Monium Khidir |date=November 2002 |title=Challenges for integrating gender into poverty alleviation programmes: Lessons from Sudan |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/13552070215922 |journal=Gender & Development |volume=10 |issue=3 |pages=22–30 |doi=10.1080/13552070215922 |s2cid=71270250 |issn=1355-2074}}</ref> Broader related topics include [[single-sex education]] and [[religious education]] for women, in which education is divided along gender lines.
Inequalities in education for girls and women are complex:<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Dekkers |first1=Hetty P.J.M. |last2=Bosker |first2=Roel J. |last3=Driessen |first3=Geert W.J.M. |date=March 2000 |title=Complex Inequalities of Educational Opportunities. A Large-Scale Longitudinal Study on the Relation Between Gender, Social Class, Ethnicity and School Success |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1076/1380-3611(200003)6:1;1-i;ft059 |journal=Educational Research and Evaluation |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=59–82 |doi=10.1076/1380-3611(200003)6:1;1-i;ft059 |s2cid=144400482 |issn=1380-3611}}</ref> [[Female education in STEM|women]] and girls face explicit barriers to entry to school, for example, violence against women or prohibitions of girls from going to school, while other problems are more systematic and less explicit, for example, [[female education in STEM|science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM)]] education disparities are deep rooted, even in Europe and North America.<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title=Cracking the code: girls' and women's education in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM)|publisher=UNESCO|year=2017|isbn=9789231002335|location=Paris}}</ref> In some Western countries, women have surpassed men at many levels of education. For example, in the United States in 2005/2006, women earned 62% of associate degrees, 58% of bachelor's degrees, 60% of master's degrees, and 50% of doctorates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nces.ed.gov/programs/digest/d07/tables/dt07_178.asp |title=Historical summary of faculty, students, degrees, and finances in degree-granting institutions: Selected years, 1869-70 through 2005-06 |publisher=Nces.ed.gov |access-date=2014-08-22}}</ref>
Improving girls' educational levels has been demonstrated to have clear impacts on the health and economic future of young women, which in turn improves the prospects of their entire community.<ref>{{cite web|title=CAMFED USA: What we do|url=http://us.camfed.org/site/PageServer?pagename=home_index|publisher=CAMFED|access-date=October 11, 2011|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009011622/http://us.camfed.org/site/PageServer?pagename=home_index|archive-date=October 9, 2011}}</ref> The [[infant mortality]] rate of babies whose mothers have received primary education is half that of children whose mothers are [[Literacy|illiterate]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Girls Education:A lifeline to development|url=http://www.unicef.org/sowc96/ngirls.htm|date=1995|access-date=2022-02-03|archive-date=2021-04-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210425183724/http://www.unicef.org/sowc96/ngirls.htm|url-status=dead}}</ref> In the poorest countries of the world, 50% of girls do not attend secondary school.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Filmer |first=Deon |date=2007-06-29 |title=If you build it, will they come? School availability and school enrolment in 21 poor countries |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00220380701384588 |journal=The Journal of Development Studies |volume=43 |issue=5 |pages=901–928 |doi=10.1080/00220380701384588 |s2cid=216140496 |issn=0022-0388}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Herz |first1=Barbara |last2=Subbarao |first2=K. |last3=Habib |first3=Masooma |last4=Raney |first4=Laura |date=1991-09-30 |title=Letting girls learn |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1596/0-8213-1937-x |journal=World Bank Discussion Papers |doi=10.1596/0-8213-1937-x |isbn=978-0-8213-1937-6 |issn=0259-210X}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Paudel |first=Ramesh C. |date=2019-12-31 |title=Collier, P. (2008). The Bottom Billion: Why the Poorest Countries are Failing and What Can be Done About It, Oxford University Press, USA. |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.3126/ejon.v42i3-4.36039 |journal=Economic Journal of Nepal |volume=42 |issue=3–4 |pages=79–82 |doi=10.3126/ejon.v42i3-4.36039 |s2cid=242154293 |issn=1018-631X}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |title=What Have We Learned About Moral Courage in Organizations? |date=2015-03-26 |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.4324/9781315702285-28 |work=Moral Courage in Organizations: Doing the Right Thing at Work |pages=235–240 |access-date=2023-03-25 |publisher=Routledge |doi=10.4324/9781315702285-28 |isbn=978-1-315-70228-5}}</ref><ref name="Grimm 771–779">{{Cite journal |last=Grimm |first=Wolfram |date=November 2006 |title=What Is Evidence-Based, What Is New in Medical Therapy of Acute Heart Failure? |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s00059-006-2910-y |journal=Herz Kardiovaskuläre Erkrankungen |volume=31 |issue=8 |pages=771–779 |doi=10.1007/s00059-006-2910-y |pmid=17149679 |s2cid=38811473 |issn=0340-9937}}</ref> Yet, research shows that every extra year of school for girls increases their lifetime income by 15%. Improving female education, and thus the earning potential of women, improves the [[standard of living]] for their own children, as women invest more of their income in their families than men do.<ref>{{cite web|title=Plan Overseas - Why Girls? |url=http://becauseiamagirl.ca/page.aspx?pid=3894 |publisher=Plan Canada |access-date=October 29, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113021252/http://becauseiamagirl.ca/Page.aspx?pid=3894 |archive-date=November 13, 2011 }}</ref> Yet, many barriers to education for girls remain. In some African countries, such as Burkina Faso, girls are unlikely to attend school for such basic reasons as a lack of private latrine facilities for girls.<ref>{{cite web|title=Plan Overseas - Education Girl-friendly schools see enrollment rates soar in Burkina Faso |url=http://becauseiamagirl.ca/page.aspx?pid=3859 |publisher=Plan Canada |access-date=October 29, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011143727/http://becauseiamagirl.ca/page.aspx?pid=3859 |archive-date=October 11, 2011 }}</ref>
Education increases a woman's (and her partner's and the family's) level of health and health awareness.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Chandra |first1=Anjani |last2=Martinez |first2=Gladys M. |last3=Mosher |first3=William D. |last4=Abma |first4=Joyce C. |last5=Jones |first5=Jo |date=2005 |title=Fertility, family planning, and reproductive health of U.S. women: Data from the 2002 National Survey of Family Growth |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/e414702008-001 |access-date=2023-03-25 |website=PsycEXTRA Dataset|doi=10.1037/e414702008-001 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation |title=Kakkar, Baron, (Ajay Kumar Kakkar) (born 28 April 1964) |date=2010-12-01 |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.u251313 |work=Who's Who |access-date=2023-03-25 |publisher=Oxford University Press|doi=10.1093/ww/9780199540884.013.u251313 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Ross |first1=Catherine E. |last2=Mirowsky |first2=John |last3=Goldsteen |first3=Karen |date=November 1990 |title=The Impact of the Family on Health: The Decade in Review |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2307/353319 |journal=Journal of Marriage and the Family |volume=52 |issue=4 |pages=1059 |doi=10.2307/353319 |jstor=353319 |s2cid=29506270 |issn=0022-2445}}</ref> Furthering women's levels of education and advanced training also tends to delay the initiation of sexual activity, first marriage, and first childbirth.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Miller |first1=Brent C. |last2=Moore |first2=Kristin A. |date=November 1990 |title=Adolescent Sexual Behavior, Pregnancy, and Parenting: Research through the 1980s |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2307/353317 |journal=Journal of Marriage and the Family |volume=52 |issue=4 |pages=1025 |doi=10.2307/353317 |jstor=353317 |issn=0022-2445}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Bongaarts] |first1=[John |last2=Rindfuss |first2=Ronald R. |last3=Morgan |first3=S. Philip |last4=Swicegood |first4=Gray |date=December 1988 |title=First Births in America: Changes in the Timing of Parenthood. |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2307/1973641 |journal=Population and Development Review |volume=14 |issue=4 |pages=747 |doi=10.2307/1973641 |jstor=1973641 |issn=0098-7921}}</ref> Moreover, more education increases the likelihood of remaining single, having no children, or having no formal marriage while increasing levels of long-term partnerships.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Harrison |first1=Abigail |last2=O’Sullivan |first2=Lucia F. |date=2010-03-31 |title=In the Absence of Marriage: Long-Term Concurrent Partnerships, Pregnancy, and HIV Risk Dynamics Among South African Young Adults |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10461-010-9687-y |journal=AIDS and Behavior |volume=14 |issue=5 |pages=991–1000 |doi=10.1007/s10461-010-9687-y |pmid=20354777 |pmc=3848496 |issn=1090-7165}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Kuperberg |first=Arielle |date=2014-03-04 |title=Age at Coresidence, Premarital Cohabitation, and Marriage Dissolution: 1985-2009 |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/jomf.12092 |journal=Journal of Marriage and Family |volume=76 |issue=2 |pages=352–369 |doi=10.1111/jomf.12092 |issn=0022-2445}}</ref> Women's education is important for [[women's health]] as well, increasing contraceptive use while lowering sexually transmitted infections, and increasing the level of resources available to women who divorce or are in a situation of domestic violence.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Leke |first1=Robert J. I. |last2=Oduma |first2=Jemimah A. |last3=Bassol-Mayagoitia |first3=Susana |last4=Bacha |first4=Angela Maria |last5=Grigor |first5=Kenneth M. |date=July 1993 |title=Regional and Geographical Variations in Infertility: Effects of Environmental, Cultural, and Socioeconomic Factors |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2307/3431379 |journal=Environmental Health Perspectives |volume=101 |issue=Suppl 2 |pages=73–80 |doi=10.2307/3431379 |jstor=3431379 |pmid=8243409 |pmc=1519926 |issn=0091-6765}}</ref> Education also improves women's communication with partners and employers and their rates of [[Civic engagement|civic participation]].<ref>{{cite web|author1=Farzaneh Roudi-Fahimi|author2=Valentine M. Moghadam|title=Empowering Women, Developing Society: Female Education in the Middle East and North Africa|url=http://www.prb.org/Publications/PolicyBriefs/EmpoweringWomenDevelopingSocietyFemaleEducationintheMiddleEastandNorthAfrica.aspx|publisher=Population Reference Bureau|access-date=October 29, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111025140101/http://www.prb.org/Publications/PolicyBriefs/EmpoweringWomenDevelopingSocietyFemaleEducationintheMiddleEastandNorthAfrica.aspx|archive-date=2011-10-25|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Population, Education and Development |date=2003 |isbn=978-92-1-151382-0 |url=https://www.un.org/esa/population/publications/concise2003/Concisereport2003.pdf|publisher=United Nations|access-date=October 29, 2011}}</ref>
Because of the wide-reaching effects of female education on society, alleviating inequalities in education for women is highlighted in [[Sustainable Development Goal 4]] "Quality Education for All", and deeply connected to [[Sustainable Development Goal 5|Sustainable Development Goal 5 "Gender Equality]]". Education of girls (and empowerment of women in general) in developing countries leads to faster development and a faster decrease of [[Human population growth|population growth]], thus playing a significant role in addressing environmental issues such as [[climate change mitigation]].<ref name="Grimm 771–779"/><ref>{{Cite journal |date=2005-12-01 |title=Taking action: achieving gender equality and empowering women |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.5860/choice.43-2525 |journal=Choice Reviews Online |volume=43 |issue=4 |pages=43–2525–43-2525 |doi=10.5860/choice.43-2525 |issn=0009-4978}}</ref> [[Drawdown (climate)|Project Drawdown]] estimates that educating girls is the sixth most efficient action against climate change (ahead of [[solar farms]] and [[nuclear power]]).<ref name=":10" />
==Issues== ===Violence against women===
[[Violence against women]] teachers became a political issue in Sweden during the period from 1900 to 1940.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Vaughan |first=Mary Kay |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2307/j.ctv1d6q40z |title=Cultural Politics in Revolution |date=1997-03-01 |publisher=University of Arizona Press |doi=10.2307/j.ctv1d6q40z |isbn=978-0-8165-4310-6}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.4324/9780203839683 |title=Global Pathways to Abolishing Physical Punishment |date=2010-12-20 |publisher=Routledge |doi=10.4324/9780203839683 |isbn=978-1-136-88635-5 |editor-last=Durrant |editor-first=Joan E. |editor-last2=Smith |editor-first2=Anne B.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |last1=Pratt |first1=John |last2=Eriksson |first2=Anna |date=2014-06-03 |title=Contrasts in Punishment |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.4324/9780203096116 |doi=10.4324/9780203096116|isbn=9780203096116 }}</ref> By 1900, 66 percent of Sweden's teachers were women, many of whom worked in isolated rural areas, where they faced loneliness and the threat of male violence. Politicians, teachers, and female authors debated a number of solutions to reduce these threats, such as providing the teachers with guard dogs, weapons, and telephones.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Backman Prytz |first1=Sara |last2=Westberg |first2=Johannes |title="Arm the Schoolmistress!" Loneliness, Male Violence, and the Work and Living Conditions of Early Twentieth-Century Teachers in Sweden |journal=History of Education Quarterly |date=2022 |volume=62 |issue=1 |pages=18–37 |doi=10.1017/heq.2021.55|s2cid=246488899 |doi-access=free }}</ref>
In Pakistan, a negative relationship was found between the formal level of education a woman attains and the likelihood of violence against that woman (After, 2013).<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Mumtaz |first1=Sarwat |last2=Bahk |first2=Jinwook |last3=Khang |first3=Young-Ho |date=2017-10-17 |title=Rising trends and inequalities in cesarean section rates in Pakistan: Evidence from Pakistan Demographic and Health Surveys, 1990-2013 |journal=PLOS ONE |volume=12 |issue=10 |pages=e0186563 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0186563 |pmid=29040316 |pmc=5645133 |bibcode=2017PLoSO..1286563M |issn=1932-6203|doi-access=free }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Blair |first1=Graeme |last2=Christine Fair |first2=C. |last3=Malhotra |first3=Neil |last4=Shapiro |first4=Jacob N. |date=2012-07-16 |title=Poverty and Support for Militant Politics: Evidence from Pakistan |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1540-5907.2012.00604.x |journal=American Journal of Political Science |volume=57 |issue=1 |pages=30–48 |doi=10.1111/j.1540-5907.2012.00604.x |issn=0092-5853}}</ref> The researcher used snowball convenient sampling, a sampling method where participants are referred. Ethical and privacy issues made this the most convenient method. An informant played a major role in gathering information that was then cross-checked. The sample of victims of violence was made up of married women from ages 18–60 both from rural and urban communities. The study described different forms of physical violence that are already present and provided an idea of what women go through, even across communities (rural and urban). Education in this study was stressed to be the solution and a necessity in eliminating violence. A discussion of political and social barriers is needed.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Khan |first1=Hafiz Muhammad Ather |last2=Sindher |first2=Riaz Hussain Khan |last3=Hussain |first3=Irshad |title=Studying the role of education in eliminating violence against women |journal=Pakistan Journal of Commerce and Social Sciences |date=2013 |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=405–416 |id={{ProQuest|1517529927}} |hdl=10419/188100 }}</ref>
The relationship is a lot more complicated than it seems, women can be illiterate but still become empowered (Marrs Fuchsel, 2014). Immigrant Latina Women (ILW) were part of a qualitative study of 8 to 10 participant groups, at a time, and completed an 11-week program centered on self-esteem, domestic violence awareness, and healthy relationships. Immigrant Latina Women (ILW) is a highly affected group by domestic violence. Though this program took place outside of a traditional classroom, dialogue, critical thinking, and emotional well-being were stressed, areas that should be acquired while in school. Lastly, though many of the women were illiterates they were still able to come away with a stronger sense of control over their own lives, an important life skill.<ref>{{cite journal |id={{ERIC|EJ1064075}} |last1=Marrs Fuchsel |first1=L. Catherine |title='Yes, I Feel Stronger with More Confidence and Strength:' Examining the Experiences of Immigrant Latina Women (ILW) Participating in the Si, Yo Puedo Curriculum |journal=Journal of Ethnographic & Qualitative Research |date=2014 |volume=9 |issue=2 |pages=161–182 }}</ref>
Different countries experience various forms of violence against women and girls, which in Nigeria, UNICEF noted 16 facts about such incidence.<ref>{{Cite web |title=UNICEF |url=https://www.unicef.org/ |access-date=2023-03-20 |website=www.unicef.org |language=en}}</ref> Some of those facts include: physical effects, psychological effects, short-term and long-term effect; effects on the victims, the children, the society among others There are factors that promote violence against women, which should be made open to the public. There is need for proper women and girl education to save them from the tragedy called violence. Development can be possible if individuals are able to learn positive habits that will shied them away from violence. World Health indicated that around the globe about 30% of women experience violence either by intimate sex mate or relatives.<ref>{{Cite web |title=BMC Women's Health |url=https://bmcwomenshealth.biomedcentral.com/ |access-date=2023-03-20 |website=BioMed Central |language=en}}</ref>
===Women's empowerment===
Education systems vary in administration, curriculum and personnel, but all have an influence on the students that they serve.<ref>{{Citation |last1=Bray |first1=Mark |title=Educational and social impact |date=2022-08-08 |work=Shadow Education in the Middle East |pages=54–61 |place=London |publisher=Routledge |last2=Hajar |first2=Anas|doi=10.4324/9781003317593-5 |isbn=9781003317593 |doi-access=free }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Alkhaldi |first1=Amal Hatem |last2=Burgess |first2=John |last3=Connell |first3=Julia |date=2014-12-01 |title=The Transfer of HRM Policies and Practices in American Multinational Hotels in Saudi Arabia |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.21632/irjbs.7.3.155-164 |journal=International Research Journal of Business Studies |volume=7 |issue=3 |pages=155–164 |doi=10.21632/irjbs.7.3.155-164 |issn=2089-6271|hdl=20.500.11937/33 |hdl-access=free }}</ref> As women have gained rights, formal education has become a symbol of progress and a step toward gender equity. In order for true gender equity to exist, a holistic approach needs to be taken. The discussion of girl power and women's education as solutions for eliminating violence against women and economic dependence on men can sometimes take dominance and result in the suppression of understanding how context, history and other factors affect women (Shenila [[Shenila Khoja-Moolji|Khoja-Moolji]], 2015). For example, when past secretary of State, [[Hillary Clinton]], referenced the tragedies of [[Malala Yousafzai]] in Pakistan and the girls kidnapping in [[Chibok]], [[Nigeria]], as comparable, using girls' education as the focus, history and context were ignored. What led to the shooting of Malala was reduced to being solely about her educating herself as a girl. United States interference, poverty, and government corruption and instability were not addressed.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Khoja-Moolji |first1=Shenila |title=Suturing Together Girls and Education: An Investigation Into the Social (Re)Production of Girls' Education as a Hegemonic Ideology |journal=Diaspora, Indigenous, and Minority Education |date=20 April 2015 |volume=9 |issue=2 |pages=87–107 |doi=10.1080/15595692.2015.1010640 |s2cid=143790091 }}</ref>
Education systems and schools play a central role in determining girls' interest in various subjects, including STEM subjects, which can contribute to women's [[empowerment]] by providing equal opportunities to access and benefit from quality STEM education.<ref name=":8" /> To enhance female literacy in Bangladesh, the government has implemented a range of programs. These initiatives encompass distributing free books to all primary schoolchildren, providing free education for girls up to the university level, and granting stipends to girls attending rural secondary schools.<ref>{{Cite web |title=UN Women Bangladesh |url=https://asiapacific.unwomen.org/en/countries/bangladesh |access-date=2023-09-14 |website=UN Women – Asia-Pacific |language=en}}</ref>
====Impact on socio-economic development==== {{Excerpt|Socioeconomic impact of female education}} A [[systematic review]] on vocational and business training for women in low- and middle-income countries summarized the evidence from thirty-five studies regarding the impacts of such training programs. The authors found that these types of programs have small positive effects on employment and income with variability across studies. They found that the effects of training may increase with a stronger gender focus of the program.<ref name="ChinenHoop2017">{{cite journal |last1=Chinen |first1=Marjorie |last2=Hoop |first2=Thomas |last3=Alcázar |first3=Lorena |last4=Balarin |first4=María |last5=Sennett |first5=Josh |title=Vocational and business training to improve women's labour market outcomes in low‐ and middle‐income countries: a systematic review |journal=Campbell Systematic Reviews |date=January 2017 |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=1–195 |doi=10.4073/csr.2017.16 |doi-access=free }}</ref>
===Environmental impact=== Education of girls (and empowerment of women in general) in developing countries leads to faster development and a faster decrease of [[Human population growth|population growth]]. It therefore has a significant impact on environmental issues such as [[climate change]]. The research network [[Drawdown (climate)|Drawdown]] estimates that educating girls is the sixth most efficient action against climate change (ahead of [[solar farms]], [[nuclear power]], [[afforestation]] and many other actions).<ref name=":10">{{cite web|url=https://www.drawdown.org/solutions/women-and-girls/educating-girls|title=EDUCATING GIRLS|publisher=Drawdown|access-date=4 July 2019|archive-date=14 October 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191014145620/https://www.drawdown.org/solutions/women-and-girls/educating-girls|url-status=dead}}</ref>
== Specific types of education ==
=== Technology education === The proliferation of digital [[technology]] and digital services has made digital skills a prerequisite for full participation in [[society]]. Today, an inability to navigate the [[internet]] poses disadvantages. While these disadvantages were once somewhat contained to wealthy countries, they are now relevant globally, due to the rapid and continuing proliferation of internet-connected technology.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|last=UNESCO, EQUALS Skills Coalition|date=2019|title=I'd blush if I could: closing gender divides in digital skills through education|url=https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000367416.pdf}}</ref>
Equipping women and girls with digital skills helps put them on equal footing with digitally savvy men, and opens up countless opportunities for increased agency and choice. [[Website]]s and mobile applications on [[health]] and [[Natural rights and legal rights|legal rights]], for example, can help women make informed decisions to safeguard and care for themselves and their families, while online social networks and [[digital communications]] allow women to disseminate information and share knowledge beyond their immediate community.<ref name=":9" />
[[M-learning|Mobile learning]] opportunities, from [[literacy]] apps to open online courses ([[MOOCs]]) about subjects as diverse as [[astronomy]] and caring for older relatives with dementia, can open up new educational pathways, especially for out-of-school girls and adult women.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Hempel |first1=Jessi |title=Siri and Cortana Sound Like Ladies Because of Sexism |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/10/why-siri-cortana-voice-interfaces-sound-female-sexism/ |magazine=Wired |date=28 October 2015 }}</ref> Job search engines and professional networking sites enable women to compete in the [[Labour Market|labour market]], while [[e-commerce]] platforms and digital banking services can help increase their [[income]] and independence.<ref name=":9" />

=== Disability === Education for disabled women has also improved. ==History==
===Africa=== Christian missionaries in the 19th century opened modern educational methods, but they usually focused on boys. After early experiments they settled on promoting ideology of domestic femininity imparted through girls' schooling.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Leach |first1=Fiona |title=Resisting conformity: Anglican mission women and the schooling of girls in early nineteenth-century West Africa |journal=History of Education |date=March 2012 |volume=41 |issue=2 |pages=133–153 |doi=10.1080/0046760X.2011.582048 |s2cid=144485341 }}</ref> In [[South Africa]] after 1820, male Scottish missionaries decided that only the most basic education was necessary to prepare native women for the propagation of Christianity within the home. They prevented female teachers from operating in the Scottish mission's territory. They delayed the establishment of a Girls' Department at [[Lovedale Institution]]. Finally new leadership arrived who had a broader vision of uplifting native women so they could promote Christianity and Western gender codes.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Erlank |first1=Natasha |title='Raising Up the Degraded Daughters of Africa': The Provision of Education for Xhosa Women in the Mid-Nineteenth Century |journal=South African Historical Journal |date=November 2000 |volume=43 |issue=1 |pages=24–38 |doi=10.1080/02582470008671906 |s2cid=143832577 }}</ref>
[[Indian diaspora in East Africa|Muslims from India who came to East Africa]] in the late 19th century brought along a highly restrictive policy against schooling for their girls.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Keshavjee |first1=Rashida |title=The elusive access to education for Muslim women in Kenya from the late nineteenth century to the 'Winds of Change' in Africa (1890s to 1960s) |journal=Paedagogica Historica |date=February 2010 |volume=46 |issue=1–2 |pages=99–115 |doi=10.1080/00309230903528488 |s2cid=143964604 }}</ref>
As of 2015, Priscilla Sitienei was attending elementary school in Kenya at age 92.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/03/02/africa/kenya-oldest-student/ |title=In Kenya, a grandmother in her 90s attends fourth grade |publisher=CNN.com |date=2015-03-02 |access-date=2015-04-17}}</ref> She died in November 2022, at the age of 99, whilst preparing for final exams.<ref>{{cite news |title=Priscilla Sitienei: 'World's oldest primary school pupil' dies aged 99 in Kenya |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-63674795 |access-date=19 November 2022 |publisher=BBC News |date=18 November 2022}}</ref>
==== West Africa ==== ===== Pre-colonial ===== {{Expand section|date=August 2019}} Women's education in West Africa manifested in both formal and informal structures, with one of the more notable structures that had influence on women's education being preparatory schools labeled "Bush Schools".<ref name=Day1998>{{cite book |last=Day |first=Lynda |chapter=Rites and Reason: Precolonial Education and Its Relevance to the Current Production and Transmission of Knowledge |pages=49–72 |editor1-last=Bloch |editor1-first=Marianne N. |editor2-last=Beoku-Betts |editor2-first=Josephine A. |editor3-last=Tabachnick |editor3-first=B. Robert |title=Women and Education in Sub-Saharan Africa: Power, Opportunities, and Constraints |date=1998 |publisher=L. Rienner Publishers |isbn=978-1-55587-704-0 }}</ref> These bush schools were institutions that would oftentimes boast near 100% graduation rates and completed courses. They were organized by women and had a planned, structured curriculum, which included learning how to do skills such as learning how to "fish, cook, weave, spin cotton, dress hair, and make baskets, musical instruments, pots, and fishing nets."<ref name=Day1998/> Much of the scholarship and research on these schools arises from the Bundu schools of Sierra Leone. In addition to these skills, girls would often be given reproductive education, such as birth control techniques or child rearing skills. In particular to the Bundu schools, women would be given an intense education in medicinal herbs and home medicinal skills.<ref name=Day1998/> These schools did not just teach educational curriculum (such as history passed on through songs and dances), but enabled the transmission of cultural values and were centers of female power. Despite the colonial and post-colonial ideal that women ought to be educated just to serve decorative or child-bearing maternal roles, these institutions taught women to play central economic, corporate and familial roles in their communities.<ref name=Day1998/>
In the 19th century, [[Nana Asmaʼu]] (1793–1864) founded the [[Yan Taru]] movement for the education of [[Sokoto Caliphate|Sokoto]] women.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Akyeampong|first1=Emmanuel Kwaku|author-link1=Emmanuel K. Akyeampong|last2= Gates, Jr.|first2=Henry Louis| author-link2= Henry Louis Gates Jr.| title= Dictionary of African Biography, Volumes 1-6|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=39JMAgAAQBAJ&dq=Yan+Taru+Nana+Asma%27u&pg=PA283|year=2012|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|page=283|isbn=9780195382075}} </ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Boyd |first1=Jean |last2=Last |first2=Murray |date=1985 |title=The Role of Women as "Agents Religieux" in Sokoto |url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/484826 |journal=Canadian Journal of African Studies |volume=19 |issue=2 |pages=283–300 |doi=10.2307/484826 |jstor=484826 |issn=0008-3968}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last=Merritt| first=Nikki| title=Nana Asma'u, Her Elegies and the Possibility of 'Insider Alternatives' | year=1994| journal=African Languages and Cultures| volume=7| issue=2| pages=91–99|doi=10.1080/09544169408717779|jstor=1771806|s2cid=191426813}}</ref>
===== Colonial ===== [[File:ASC Leiden - Coutinho Collection - D 33 - Hermangono, Guinea-Bissau - Pupils at the northern front - 1974.tif|thumb|Three high-school girls in Hermangono, [[Guinea-Bissau]], during the [[Portuguese Colonial War|colonial war]], 1974]] Early colonial forms of education on the West African coasts, particularly among the [[Dahomey]], [[Ashanti people|Asante]] and [[Yoruba people|Yorùbá]] people, were pioneered by missionaries and institutions that were trying to educate religious thought in addition to teaching more traditional western educational topics such as reading and writing.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The History of Education in Ghana: From the Earliest Times to the Declaration of Independence|last=Graham|first=C.K.|publisher=Routeledge|year=1971}}{{page needed|date=March 2021}}</ref> As early as 1529, King John III of Portugal had given instruction to open schools and provide education in "religious thought, reading and writing" and for the instructors to be paid by the pupil.<ref name=":1" /> For women in particular however, these colonial forms of education brought with them European ideals of women's roles in the family, society and economy. These Western ideas of womanhood oftentimes contrasted with women's roles in the economy, society, or in the home.<ref name=pmid11639388>{{cite journal |last1=Allman |first1=Jean |title=Making Mothers: Missionaries, Medical Officers and Women's Work in Colonial Asante, 1924–1945 |journal=History Workshop Journal |date=1 October 1994 |volume=38 |issue=1 |pages=23–47 |doi=10.1093/hwj/38.1.23 |pmid=11639388 |s2cid=12012354 }}</ref> For example, [[Igbo people|Igbo]] women had associations known as [[Sitting on a man|Mikiri]], which were economic and social forums for women in which they discussed direct action to enforce their interests, which were largely misunderstood and disregarded by various British colonial administrations. Hence, as the colonial administrations introduced schools to the region, they ignored educating women to fill economic roles in the community.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Van Allen |first1=Judith |title='Sitting on a Man': Colonialism and the Lost Political Institutions of Igbo Women |journal=Canadian Journal of African Studies |date=January 1972 |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=165–181 |doi=10.1080/00083968.1972.10803664 }}</ref> In fact, the educational ideal of men as "[[Breadwinner model|breadwinners]]", i.e. the primary financial support of a nuclear family structure, was introduced by successive British colonial governments in West Africa.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Africa After Gender?|last=Lindsay|first=Lisa|publisher=Indiana University Press|year=2007|location=Bloomington|pages=Chapter: Working with Gender: The Emergence of the "Male Breadwinner" in Colonial Southwestern Nigeria}}{{page needed|date=March 2021}}</ref>
One of the groups of people that the colonial governments in West Africa put heavy import on educating were the mixed children of white people, typically men, and indigenous people, typically women. In pre-British era of Ghanaian history, when much of the interaction between indigenous people and Europeans was through Dutch traders, mixed race children of traders and indigenous people were removed from their indigenous communities and placed in Dutch educational institutions in Ghana.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|title=Crossing the Color Line: Race, Sex, and the Contested Politics of Colonialism in Ghana|last=Ray|first=Carina|publisher=Ohio University Press|year=2016|location=Athens}}{{page needed|date=March 2021}}</ref> In these early colonial schools the education was also gendered by Western standards: the boys were educated from a young age to be military officers in the Dutch army and the girls were educated to be married to Dutch military officers in the region.<ref name=":3" />
One of the other ways through which colonizing countries were able to exert influence and indirect rule over the indigenous people was through maternal education. In colonial Ghana, [[Methodist Church of Great Britain|Methodist]] missionaries led classes teaching western methods of hygiene and child birth to the indigenous mothers or mothers-to-be.<ref name=pmid11639388/> The missionaries tried to construct an ideal of motherhood that matched white European middle-class standards, irrespective of the social context of the ideals of motherhood in place in the [[Ashanti Empire|Asante]] societies they were located in.<ref name=pmid11639388/>
===== Contemporary ===== In post-colonial West Africa, many of the ideals of Western education have remained while much of the infrastructure and funding left with the colonial presence.<ref name=":4">{{cite book |last1=Hollos |first1=Marida |chapter=The Status of Women in Southern Nigeria: Is Education a Help or a Hindrance? |pages=247–276 |editor1-last=Bloch |editor1-first=Marianne N. |editor2-last=Beoku-Betts |editor2-first=Josephine A. |editor3-last=Tabachnick |editor3-first=B. Robert |title=Women and Education in Sub-Saharan Africa: Power, Opportunities, and Constraints |date=1998 |publisher=L. Rienner Publishers |isbn=978-1-55587-704-0 }}</ref> Particularly in Nigeria, formal education was seen as a policy making tool, as women's formal education has been linked to having effects on "population growth, health, nutrition, fertility, infant mortality, and changes in women's productivity and earnings."<ref>{{Cite book|title=Female Participation in Education in Sub-Saharan Africa|last=UNESCO Division of Statistics, African|publisher=UNESCO Division of Statistics, African Academy of Sciences|year=1995|location=Nairobi}}</ref> Researchers have cited some disadvantages however to this reliance on women's formal education. One, there is concern for women being alienated from their indigenous cultures and not receiving the education in values that were typically received through pre-colonial indigenous educational systems.<ref name=":4" /> In addition, there is an increasing body of literature that suggests how the formal education institutions channel women into particular lower-earning job fields such as the humanities, while guiding women away from more technical jobs with higher wages.<ref name=":4" />
In regards to academic achievement, according to the FAWE Conference girls across the Sub-Saharan region reported lower scores in Math and Science subjects.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title=The Education of Girls and Women in Africa|last=Gachukia|first=Edduh|publisher=Forum for African Women Educationalists|year=1995|location=Nairobi}}</ref> The tendency for girls to be pushed into clerical positions upon finishing school is also a widely researched and held belief.<ref name=":4" /> Despite this, formal education offers many benefits recognized internationally. The Fourth United Nations World Conference on Women has released publications citing numerous ways through which women's education in Africa is beneficial to society as a whole. These entail an increase in family health, in higher wage jobs available to women, an improvement in quality standards of childhood development, and a greater inclusion of women in decisions making that can impact a nation in environmental, political, social and economic ways.<ref name=":5" /> Despite there being a drop in participation of women in education in the majority of countries in West Africa in the 1950s and 1960s, rates of women education have been steadily climbing since then. However, there is still much statistical gender disparity as according to UNESCO statistics on women's enrollment and graduation rates.
Due to handicapes made for the afghan women and girls for getting education by Taliban government, United nations dedicated 2023 World education day to the afghan girls and women.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Iqbal |first=Anwar |date=2023-01-24 |title=UN dedicates World Education Day to Afghan girls and women |url=https://www.dawn.com/news/1733328 |access-date=2023-01-25 |website=DAWN.COM |language=en}}</ref>
===== Gender disparities ===== One of the primary ways in which there are gender disparities in education in West Africa are in the ratios of male to female participation: 43.6% of men have completed primary education as opposed to 35.4% of women, 6.0% of men have completed secondary education as opposed to 3.3% of women, and 0.7% of men have completed tertiary education as opposed to 0.2% of women.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Stromquist |first1=Nelly P. |chapter=Agents in Women's Education: Some Trends in the African Context |pages=25–46 |editor1-last=Bloch |editor1-first=Marianne N. |editor2-last=Beoku-Betts |editor2-first=Josephine A. |editor3-last=Tabachnick |editor3-first=B. Robert |title=Women and Education in Sub-Saharan Africa: Power, Opportunities, and Constraints |date=1998 |publisher=L. Rienner Publishers |isbn=978-1-55587-704-0 }}</ref> Some of the reasons for poor enrollment and participation is the "male breadwinner" ideal that prioritizes educating boys over girls and limited funds available to families for education. In addition, in West Africa women are seen as the primary providers of [[Care work|unpaid care work]]. This offers competing demands on the time of girls and oftentimes their families will prioritize girls' spending time taking care of siblings or doing [[domestic labor]].<ref name=":5" /> In addition, a leading cause of gender disparities in education are gender disparities in the labor market, which lead to gendered ideas of women's role in a society.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Vavrus |first1=Frances |last2=Bloch |first2=Marianne |chapter=Gender and Educational Research, Policy and Practice in Sub-Saharan Africa: Theoretical and Empirical Problems and Prospects |pages=1–24 |editor1-last=Bloch |editor1-first=Marianne N. |editor2-last=Beoku-Betts |editor2-first=Josephine A. |editor3-last=Tabachnick |editor3-first=B. Robert |title=Women and Education in Sub-Saharan Africa: Power, Opportunities, and Constraints |date=1998 |publisher=L. Rienner Publishers |isbn=978-1-55587-704-0 }}</ref>
In addition to this, some gender disparities are caused by teacher's attitudes towards students in the classroom according to the students' gender.<ref name=":6">{{cite book |last1=Anderson-Levitt |first1=Kathryn M. |last2=Bloch |first2=Marianne |last3=Soumare |first3=Aminata M. |chapter=Inside Classrooms in Guinea: Girls' Experiences |pages=99–130 |editor1-last=Bloch |editor1-first=Marianne N. |editor2-last=Beoku-Betts |editor2-first=Josephine A. |editor3-last=Tabachnick |editor3-first=B. Robert |title=Women and Education in Sub-Saharan Africa: Power, Opportunities, and Constraints |date=1998 |publisher=L. Rienner Publishers |isbn=978-1-55587-704-0 }}</ref> There are some preconceived notions that boys are more intelligent and harder working than girls in some West African countries. In particular in [[Guinea]], surveys have been taken by researchers suggesting that school teachers, particularly in rural schools, believe that boys learn lessons better, have more ambition, are smarter, and work harder, while girls make less effort, rarely give good responses to questions, and use poor French expression.<ref name=":6" /> In addition in both urban and rural schools analyzed, girls were expected to do the manual labor to keep the schools clean while this expectation was not held for the boys.<ref name=":6" />
Gender disparities in higher education persist as well, with women accounting for a little over 20% of university level enrollment in all of Sub-Saharan Africa, and countries in West Africa such as Niger and Ghana reporting rates of 15% and 21%, respectively.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Beoku-Betts|first=Josephine|date=1998|title=Gender and Formal Education in Africa: An Exploration of the Opportunity Structure at the Secondary and Tertiary Levels}}</ref> This is considered a contributing factor to why there are so few women in higher-level management and administrative jobs.<ref name=":5" /> In Ghana in 1990, women made up less than 1% of managers in the labor market, but with an average annual growth rate of 3.2%.<ref name=":7" /> Researchers hope that improving primary education attainment and accomplishment will lead to more attainment and accomplishment in the tertiary educational level and in the labor market.<ref name=":5" />
==== Gender equality in African education ==== In the past few decades, African countries have attached great importance to the role of education in the process of nation-state construction and development. Therefore, education has been placed on the policy priorities, and the rapid expansion of the number of educational institutions at all levels has greatly increased women's educational opportunities. In particular, after the World Conference on Education for All, women's education received special attention in Africa and achieved rapid development.<ref name=":25">{{Cite book|title=Women's literacy in worldwide perspective|last=Leslie|first=Limage|year=1994}}</ref>
===== Progress ===== Taking Sub-Saharan Africa as an example: in early 1960, the gross enrollment rate of girls in primary education, secondary education and higher education was 25%, 1% and 0.1%, respectively. By 2006, the figures were 89%, 28% and 4%, respectively.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last1=Dunne|first1=Máiréad|last2=Sayed|first2=Yusuf|date=2002|title=Transformation and Equity: Women and Higher Education in Sub-Saharan Africa|journal=International Studies in Educational Administration|volume=30|issue=1|pages=50}}</ref>
While the enrollment rate of women at all levels is increasing, the gender parity index is also improving. In sub-Saharan Africa, the gender parity index for primary school enrollment in 1980, 1990, 2000 and 2006 was 0.77, 0.81, 0.89, and 0.92, respectively. In some countries, women's gross enrollment ratios even exceed men's gross enrollment rates, such as the Gambia, Ghana, Malawi, and Zambia. The gender parity index for secondary and higher education also tends to increase.<ref name=":02" />
In addition to the enrollment rate and gender parity index, other indicators, such as repetition rates, dropout rates, graduation rates, etc., also reflect the progress of women's education in Africa. In 1999, the repetition rate of female primary education in Sub-Saharan African countries was 17.7%, and in 2006 it fell to 13.3%. At the same time, the increase in female enrollment rates has also led to a growing number of female teachers in Africa.<ref name=":02" />
===== Challenge ===== In recent decades, female education in Africa has made great (though uneven) progress. On the one hand, the level of development of women's education between countries and countries in this region is still significantly different due to differences in geographical location, social class, language and ethnicity. On the other hand, compared with the rest of the world, Africa, especially in Sub-Saharan Africa, still lags behind in the field of women's education.<ref name=":16">{{cite book |doi=10.1007/978-3-319-12688-3_12 |chapter=Gender and Mathematics Education Revisited |title=The Proceedings of the 12th International Congress on Mathematical Education |year=2015 |last1=Leder |first1=Gilah C. |pages=145–170 |isbn=978-3-319-10685-4 }}</ref> Educational interventions in conflict-affected regions must adopt a more holistic and culturally sensitive approach to reshape gender norms and foster sustainable peace-building efforts. <ref>{{Cite journal |last=Datzberger |first=Simone |last2=Le Mat |first2=Marielle L. J. |date=2018-03-01 |title=Just add women and stir?: Education, gender and peacebuilding in Uganda |url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0738059317300342 |journal=International Journal of Educational Development |volume=59 |pages=61–69 |doi=10.1016/j.ijedudev.2017.09.006 |issn=0738-0593}}</ref>
Compared with men, women in most African countries have been disadvantaged in education, and the higher the level of education, the more unfavorable the situation. One of the most important reasons for this "vertical separation" is that girls' academic performance is worse than that of boys, and the percentage of students who can graduate and pass the exam is low. At the same time, in the diversion of secondary education and higher education, there is also a "level separation" of gender, which means that boys and girls are concentrated in certain classes and majors, so that these courses become male-dominated subjects or female-dominated subjects. For example, in the fields of education, humanities, and art, the proportion of girls generally far exceeds that of boys. Science, engineering, and architecture are dominated by boys.<ref name=":16"/>
==== Obstacles ==== There are gender differences in education in Africa, and the factors that lead to these differences are manifold. The factors that hinder the education of gender equality can be roughly divided into economic factors, school-related factors, and social and cultural factors.<ref name=":16"/><ref name=":33">{{Cite book|title=Socio-Cultural and Economic Factors Affecting Primary Education of Maasai Girls in Loitokitok District, Kenya.|last=Nkoyiai|first=Anastasia|publisher=Western Journal of Black Studies|year=2011}}</ref>
===== Economic ===== Family economic status is an important factor in determining whether a parent is capable of withstanding the direct and indirect costs of a child's education. Direct costs include tuition, school uniform fees, transportation fees and other material fees like textbooks. In Kenya, 47% of the rural population and 27% of the urban population live below the poverty line, yet they have to bear nearly 60% of the cost of primary education. This forces them to selectively educate their children. For poor families, girls are the most direct victims when education costs are unaffordable. In a survey in the mid-1990s, 58% of respondents let their daughters to drop out, while only 27% of respondents chose sons.<ref name=":33"/>
Compared with boys, the [[opportunity cost]] of girls to go to school is higher, because they bear multiple roles such as family workers and mothers' assistants, and they have to bear more labor than men. For example, in a province of Zambia, girls spend four times as much time on direct productive labor as boys. Therefore, girls' late schooling, absenteeism and dropouts are closely related to labor.<ref name=":16"/>
===== School-related ===== The location of the school has a direct impact on the type of education that women receive, the quality of education, and the time of education. Many parents are unwilling to let young children go to school far away from home, and the distance between the school and the home is very common in rural Africa. Insufficient infrastructure such as school teaching, health, and dormitory can also prevent women from entering school. At the same time, the curriculum and related teachers, syllabus, textbooks and teaching methods lack gender awareness, or exist gender bias, which has far more adverse effects for girls than boys. In many African countries, it is still to strengthen the society's perception of women's family life, and to hide the prejudice that women's intelligence is not as good as men's. In such a learning environment, women's learning attitudes are often negative, and they cannot fully exert their abilities. In the secondary and higher education stages, women are usually assigned to learn courses that are more feminine, such as home economics, craft classes or biology (biological is considered to be related to women's traditional occupations, such as nursing).<ref name=":16"/>
In addition, various forms of sexual violence and sexual harassment in schools, or concerns about sexual violence and sexual harassment, are silent barriers to girls' enrollment. These behaviors not only affect the school's academic performance, but also cause pregnancy, early marriage and so on. At the same time, in many countries, teenage pregnancy almost interrupted girls' school education.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bisika |first1=Thomas |last2=Ntata |first2=Pierson |last3=Konyani |first3=Sidon |title=Gender-violence and education in Malawi: a study of violence against girls as an obstruction to universal primary school education |journal=Journal of Gender Studies |date=1 September 2009 |volume=18 |issue=3 |pages=287–294 |doi=10.1080/09589230903057183 |s2cid=72635362 }}</ref>
===== Social ===== Africa's deep-rooted attitude towards women may be traced back to the patriarchal system that continued in African native culture and colonial experience. Traditionally, women's reproductive and family roles are of great value. Adolescent African girls feel this pressure strongly because she either assists her mother or other female relatives to complete their home tasks or achieves a transition to an adult role such as a wife or mother at this time. From that age, some girls who are still in elementary school are at risk of interrupting their studies. The traditional concept of marriage in Africa regards investment in women's education as a waste, that is, all proceeds flow to another family. Therefore, it is often difficult for women to get care from their father and thus lose many educational opportunities.<ref name=":16"/>
Many tribes in different parts of the world, do not advocate women education. Their cultural values are violated in case of disobeyance of their ancestors.
==== Policy interventions ====
===== Cost-related ===== Effectively promote universal, free and compulsory basic education, reduce or eliminate the direct cost of basic education, so that primary education can be more affordable. For example, in 2001, Tanzania implemented free primary education, resulting in a rapid increase in the gross enrollment rate of women's primary education from 61.6% to 88.8%.<ref name=":25"/><ref name=":33" />
===== Schools ===== Schools create a safe and fair learning environment and institutional culture that is conducive to women. Gender considerations will be taken into account in the supply and allocation of resources to meet women's specific educational needs. More important is to strengthen gender awareness education for all teachers and educators.<ref name=":25"/>
===== Governments ===== The government plays an important role in advancing gender equality in education. One of its roles is to create a good environment through laws and policies to promote women's education to achieve gender equality. Beyond the law, the government must also set up a clear framework. For example, in Ethiopia, the government clearly stipulates that women and men have the same opportunity to accept the same curriculum, and are free to choose a profession to ensure that women have the same employment opportunities as men.<ref name=":25"/>
